Question: Which reading is given to one tenth of a millimetre?
Two forces X and Y act as shown. /n Which diagram shows the resultant force R of X and Y? /n A R /n B R /n C R /n D R
Which reading is given to one tenth of a millimetre? /n A 3.3 cm /n B 3.31 cm /n C 3.310 cm /n D 3.312 cm

The magnitudes of three different electric charges are given below. /n What is the correct order of size, from largest to smallest? /n A 1 mC → 1 MC → 1 kC /n B 1 MC → 1 mC → 1 kC /n C 1 MC → 1 kC → 1 mC /n D 1 kC → 1 mC → 1 MC

Four of the gravitational forces that act between bodies in the Solar System are listed below. /n Which two forces are a Newton's third law pair (action and reaction)? /n A P and Q /n B P and R /n C Q and S /n D R and S

A hot-air balloon is travelling at constant velocity and is at a constant height above the ground. /n Which statement is correct? /n A W and Y are equal, X and Z are equal. /n B W and Y are equal, X is greater than Z. /n C X and Z are equal, Y is greater than W. /n D Y is greater than W, X is greater than Z.

Options.A: W and Y are equal, X and Z are equal.
Options.B: W and Y are equal, X is greater than Z.
Options.C: X and Z are equal, Y is greater than W.
Options.D: Y is greater than W, X is greater than Z.

Question: The diagram represents an object O moving from X to Y along a circular path at constant speed. /n What is the direction of the resultant force on O in the position shown? /n A /n B /n C /n D

Four objects of different masses are situated in places with different gravitational field strengths. /n Which object has the greatest weight? /n A 3.0 kg 10.4 N /n B 3.5 kg 9.5 N /n C 4.0 kg 10.2 N /n D 4.5 kg 9.0 N
A uniform metre rule is balanced by a 4.0 N weight as shown. /n What is the weight W of the metre rule? /n A 1.0 N /n B 4.0 N /n C 16 N /n D 40 N

Which statement about centre of mass is correct? /n A Objects with a centre of mass at the same height are less stable when the base is larger. /n B Objects with a centre of mass at the same height are more stable when the base is larger. /n C Objects with higher centres of mass and smaller bases are more stable. /n D Objects with identical bases are more stable when the centre of mass is higher.

Options.A: Objects with a centre of mass at the same height are less stable when the base is larger.
Options.B: Objects with a centre of mass at the same height are more stable when the base is larger.
Options.C: Objects with higher centres of mass and smaller bases are more stable.
Options.D: Objects with identical bases are more stable when the centre of mass is higher.

Question: A garden table weighs 60 N and has a top surface of area 2.0 m2. /n It is raining and the rain produces a pressure of 4.0 N / m2 on the table. /n Ignoring the pressure of the atmosphere, what is the force exerted by the table on the ground? /n A 52 N /n B 58 N /n C 62 N /n D 68 N

The diagram shows a manometer containing mercury that is sealed at one end. /n What happens to the distance h when the manometer is taken higher up a mountain? /n A It decreases, because atmospheric pressure decreases with height. /n B It decreases, because atmospheric pressure increases with height. /n C It increases, because atmospheric pressure decreases with height. /n D It increases, because atmospheric pressure increases with height.

Options.A: It decreases, because atmospheric pressure decreases with height.
Options.B: It decreases, because atmospheric pressure increases with height.
Options.C: It increases, because atmospheric pressure decreases with height.
Options.D: It increases, because atmospheric pressure increases with height.

Question: Some doctors measure blood pressure by using a mercury manometer. /n Blood pressure varies by 5.6 kPa as a heart beats. /n The density of mercury is 14 000 kg / m3 and the gravitational field strength g is 10 N / kg. /n What is the change in the height difference between the levels in the manometer during a heartbeat? /n A 40 mm /n B 80 mm /n C 400 mm /n D 800 mm
The diagram shows a stationary fairground ride with four chairs of equal mass. /n Which chair has the most gravitational potential energy? /n A /n B /n C /n D

The diagram shows a small car of mass 500 kg approaching a hill. /n Ignoring friction, how much work is done in moving the car up the hill? /n A 5.0 × 103 J /n B 5.0 × 104 J /n C 1.0 × 105 J /n D 1.0 × 106 J

Which statement is correct? /n A Infrared radiation cannot travel in a vacuum. /n B Infrared radiation cannot travel in solids or in gases. /n C Infrared radiation can only travel in a vacuum. /n D Infrared radiation can travel in a vacuum and in gases.

Options.A: Infrared radiation cannot travel in a vacuum.
Options.B: Infrared radiation cannot travel in solids or in gases.
Options.C: Infrared radiation can only travel in a vacuum.
Options.D: Infrared radiation can travel in a vacuum and in gases.

Question: The diagram shows a set of apparatus used to determine the specific heat capacity of water. /n What does not affect the rate at which energy is lost to the surroundings? /n A insulating the container /n B placing a lid on the container /n C polishing the outer surface of the container /n D moving the thermometer closer to the heater

Options.B: placing a lid on the container
Options.C: polishing the outer surface of the container
Options.D: moving the thermometer closer to the heater

Question: Two thermometers X and Y contain different liquids but are otherwise identical. /n Which is the more sensitive thermometer and which is the thermometer with the larger range? /n more sensitive thermometer /n thermometer with the larger range /n A X /n B X /n C Y /n D Y

The diagram shows two thermometers P and Q that are identical except that P contains less mercury. /n Which statement is correct? /n A The lowest measureable temperature is the same on P and on Q. /n B The range of P is equal to the range of Q. /n C The scales on P and Q are both linear. /n D The sensitivity of P is equal to the sensitivity of Q.

Options.A: The lowest measureable temperature is the same on P and on Q.
Options.B: The range of P is equal to the range of Q.
Options.C: The scales on P and Q are both linear.
Options.D: The sensitivity of P is equal to the sensitivity of Q.

Question: The diagram shows air trapped in a flask by a small volume of water in a thin tube. /n When the flask is held in a student's hands, the small volume of water first moves down from P to Q, and then up to R. /n Why does the small volume of water move like this? /n A The flask contracts and then the air expands. /n B The flask expands and then the air contracts. /n C The flask expands and then the air expands less than the flask. /n D The flask expands and then the air expands more than the flask.

Options.A: The flask contracts and then the air expands.
Options.B: The flask expands and then the air contracts.
Options.C: The flask expands and then the air expands less than the flask.
Options.D: The flask expands and then the air expands more than the flask.

Question: Which statement about particles in a liquid is correct? /n A They all have the same speed. /n B They are stationary. /n C They move at random. /n D They vibrate about a fixed point.

Options.A: They all have the same speed.
Options.D: They vibrate about a fixed point.

Question: A gas is enclosed in a container of fixed volume. /n The gas gains heat energy from an external source. /n What happens to the molecules of the gas? /n A They expand. /n B They move faster inside the container. /n C They move further apart. /n D They vibrate with greater frequency.

Options.B: They move faster inside the container.

Question: Which waves are longitudinal? /n A gamma rays /n B light waves /n C ultrasound waves /n D X-rays

A ray of light strikes a plane mirror at an angle of incidence of 20°. /n The angle of incidence is then increased by 5°. /n What is the new angle between the incident ray and the reflected ray? /n A 10° /n B 25° /n C 45° /n D 50°

A parallel beam of light is incident on a thin diverging lens. /n The focal length of the lens is FL, as shown in the diagram. /n Which ray diagram shows the beam after it has passed through the lens? /n A F L /n B F L /n C F L /n D F L

The following lists show colours of the spectrum. /n Which list shows these colours in order of increasing frequency? /n A blue, violet, red, orange, yellow, green /n B green, blue, violet, red, orange, yellow /n C red, orange, violet, yellow, green, blue /n D red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet

Options.A: blue, violet, red, orange, yellow, green
Options.B: green, blue, violet, red, orange, yellow
Options.C: red, orange, violet, yellow, green, blue
Options.D: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet

Question: Four sound waves are displayed on the screen of a cathode-ray oscilloscope. /n Which sound wave gets louder and has a pitch that decreases? /n A /n B /n C /n D

A student investigates a permanent magnet by suspending paper clips from the magnet as shown. /n Which statement is correct? /n A Each paper clip has a S-pole at the top and a N-pole at the bottom when suspended from the permanent magnet. /n B If the paper clips are made of soft iron they become demagnetised when the permanent magnet is removed. /n C If the paper clips are made of steel they become demagnetised when the permanent magnet is removed. /n D More paper clips can be suspended from the N-pole.

Options.A: Each paper clip has a S-pole at the top and a N-pole at the bottom when suspended from the permanent magnet.
Options.B: If the paper clips are made of soft iron they become demagnetised when the permanent magnet is removed.
Options.C: If the paper clips are made of steel they become demagnetised when the permanent magnet is removed.
Options.D: More paper clips can be suspended from the N-pole.

Question: Two vertical wires pass at right-angles through a piece of card. /n There is a large current in each wire in the direction shown. /n A plotting compass is placed on the card. /n Which diagram shows the direction in which the needle of the plotting compass points? /n A /n B /n C /n D

The diagram shows a car ignition switch and starter motor. /n The ignition switch is in a circuit with long, thin wires. /n The starter motor is in a circuit with short, thick wires. /n What is the explanation for the choice of wires? /n A Each circuit needs to contain the same total mass of wire. /n B Thicker wires heat up more quickly when the relay is switched on. /n C Thin wires have lower resistances. /n D The ignition switch circuit carries a smaller current than the starter motor circuit.

Options.A: Each circuit needs to contain the same total mass of wire.
Options.B: Thicker wires heat up more quickly when the relay is switched on.
Options.D: The ignition switch circuit carries a smaller current than the starter motor circuit.

Question: The diagram shows some white plastic beads in a clear plastic box. /n The box is shaken and the beads rub against the box. /n The beads stick to the inside surface of the box. /n Which row is a possible explanation for this? /n A gains electrons no change of electrons /n B loses electrons gain electrons /n C no change of electrons lose electrons /n D no change of electrons gain electrons

Options.A: gains electrons no change of electrons
Options.C: no change of electrons lose electrons
Options.D: no change of electrons gain electrons

Question: Which unit is the same as a volt? /n A ampere / ohm /n B ampere / watt /n C ohm / ampere /n D watt / ampere

The voltage / current graph for a metal wire is shown. /n What does the gradient of this graph represent? /n A the charge passing through the wire /n B the e.m.f. of the battery connected to the wire /n C the energy produced in the wire /n D the resistance of the wire

Options.A: the charge passing through the wire
Options.B: the e.m.f. of the battery connected to the wire
Options.C: the energy produced in the wire

Question: What is the symbol for a device that measures current? /n A /n B /n C /n D

The cable to an electric cooker contains a live wire, a neutral wire and an earth wire. /n When the cooker is working correctly, in which wires are the currents equal? /n A the live, the neutral and the earth /n B the live and the earth only /n C the neutral and the earth only /n D the neutral and the live only

Options.A: the live, the neutral and the earth
Options.B: the live and the earth only
Options.C: the neutral and the earth only
Options.D: the neutral and the live only

Question: The coil of a simple motor lies between the poles of a permanent magnet. /n The coil rotates about its axis when there is a current in it. /n What decreases the frequency of rotation of the coil? /n A increasing the number of turns in the coil /n B reversing the current /n C using a lower voltage supply /n D using a stronger magnet

Options.A: increasing the number of turns in the coil

Question: A beam of electrons travels through a vacuum. /n The beam passes between the poles of a magnet as shown. /n What is the direction of the conventional current and what is the direction of the magnetic field? /n A direction of the conventional current → direction of the magnetic field ↓ /n B direction of the conventional current → direction of the magnetic field ↑ /n C direction of the conventional current ← direction of the magnetic field ↓ /n D direction of the conventional current ← direction of the magnetic field ↑

Options.A: direction of the conventional current → direction of the magnetic field ↓
Options.B: direction of the conventional current → direction of the magnetic field ↑
Options.C: direction of the conventional current ← direction of the magnetic field ↓
Options.D: direction of the conventional current ← direction of the magnetic field ↑

Question: A teacher uses the circuit shown. /n The identical lamps X and Y are connected to a low voltage a.c. power supply by high resistance transmission wires. /n Both lamps are switched on. /n Lamp X is then switched off. /n Lamp Y stays switched on. /n What happens to the voltage and the power supplied to lamp Y? /n A the voltage supplied to lamp Y decreases, the power supplied to lamp Y decreases /n B the voltage supplied to lamp Y decreases, the power supplied to lamp Y stays the same /n C the voltage supplied to lamp Y increases, the power supplied to lamp Y increases /n D the voltage supplied to lamp Y increases, the power supplied to lamp Y stays the same

Options.A: the voltage supplied to lamp Y decreases, the power supplied to lamp Y decreases
Options.B: the voltage supplied to lamp Y decreases, the power supplied to lamp Y stays the same
Options.C: the voltage supplied to lamp Y increases, the power supplied to lamp Y increases
Options.D: the voltage supplied to lamp Y increases, the power supplied to lamp Y stays the same

Question: A car battery supplies a current in one direction. /n A current in the opposite direction recharges the battery. /n Which circuit recharges the battery, using an alternating current (a.c.) supply and a diode? /n A a.c. supply + – /n B a.c. supply + – /n C a.c. supply + – /n D a.c. supply + –
A neutral atom of boron contains 5 electrons and 5 protons. /n The nucleon number (mass number) of the atom is 11. /n How many neutrons are there in the atom? /n A 1 /n B 5 /n C 6 /n D 11
